content: उपसर्गः {@--1@} Sickness, disease, change occasioned by a disease; also a disease superinduced on another; क्षीणं हन्युश्चोपसर्गाः प्रभूताः <ls>Suśr.</ls> {@--2@} Misfortune, trouble, calamity, injury, harm; प्रशमिताशेषोपसर्गाः प्रजाः <ls>Ratn. 1. 10</ls>; सोपसर्गं वो नक्षत्रं <ls>M. 4.</ls> {@--3@} Portent, natural phenomenon foreboding evil. {@--4@} An eclipse. {@--5@} An indication or symptom of death. {@--6@} Addition. {@--7@} Possession by an evil spirit. {@--8@} A preposition prefixed to roots; निपाताश्चादयो ज्ञेयाः प्रादयस्तूपसर्गकाः . द्योतकत्वात् क्रियायोगे लोकादवगता इमे .. {%Upasargas%} are 20 in number:-- प्र, परा, अप, सम्, अनु, अव, निस् or निर्, दुस् or दुर्, वि, आ (ङ्), नि, अधि, अपि, अति, सु, उत्, अभि, प्रति, परि, उप; or 22 if निस्-निर् and दुस्-दुर् be taken as separate words. There are two theories as to the character of these prepositions. According to one theory roots have various meanings in themselves (अनेकार्था हि धातवः); when prepositions are prefixed to them they simply bring to light those meanings already existent but hidden in them, but they do not {%express%} them, being meaningless themselves; <ab>cf.</ab> <ls>Śi. 10. 15</ls>:-- संतमेव चिरमप्रकृतत्वादप्रकाशितमदिद्युतदंगे . विभ्रमं मधुमदः प्रमदानां धातुलीनमुपसर्ग इवार्थम् ... According to the other theory prepositions {%express%} their own independent meanings; they modify, intensify, and sometimes entirely alter, the senses of roots; <ab>cf.</ab> <ls>Sk.</ls>: --उपसर्गेण धात्वर्थो बलादन्यत्र नीयते . प्रहाराहारसंहारविहारपरिहारवत् .. <ab>cf.</ab> also धात्वर्थं बाधते कश्चित्कश्चित्तमनुवर्तते . तमेव विशिनष्ट्यन्य उपसर्गगतिस्त्रिधा .. (The latter theory appears to be more correct. For a fuller exposition see Nirukta).
